page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 13)
text_chunk: A full-time equivalent corresponds to one year of work by a full-time student and corresponds to an annual workload of 1650 working hours corresponding to 60 ECTS credits (European Credit Transfer System).

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 14)
text_chunk:
The workload includes scheduled classes, preparation for classes, completion of written assignments, other teaching activities, independent study as well as preparation for, and participation in examinations.
Admission requirements and qualifying degrees
1A.
The CBS bachelor degree Bachelor of Science (BSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy gives the right to admission to the MSc in Business Administration and Philosophy programme, even if there are a limited number of places offered. A precondition for this right to admission is that the applicant is admitted to this programme no later than three years after completion of the bachelor’s degree.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 15)
text_chunk:
This right to admission can only be used once.
(2) The following bachelor degrees also give access to admission to this programme, see however subsections (4) and (6):
BSc in Business Administration & Sociology (CBS)
BSc in Business, Language & Culture  (CBS)
BSc in Business, Asian Language & Culture (CBS)
HA(kom.) (CBS)
HA(psyk.) (CBS)
RUC bachelor with both "Filosofi og videnskabsteori" and "Virksomhedsstudier" (RUC)
"Erhvervsøkonomi med tilvalg i filosofi" (AU).
(3) Admission to the MSc in Business Administration and Philosophy programme requires that the applicant has completed a qualifying bachelor degree, among these a professional bachelor degree, or other Danish or foreign degree at the same level. During the education the applicant must have covered the following academic disciplines to a sufficient degree on an overall, individual assessment:
30 ECTS-points in Philosophy and/or Social Theory and/or Sociology
5 ECTS-points in Economics
25 ECTS-points in Business Administration.
(4) The requirements for language skills are available on CBS’ homepage:
cbs.dk/graduateadmission
.
(5) Standard assessments of a number of degrees from CBS or other universities are available on
cbs.dk/graduateadmission
.
(6) In the event that there are more applicants who fulfil the admission requirements than there are places offered at this programme, the selection shall be made according to criteria laid down in advance and published on
cbs.dk/graduateadmission
.
(7) Available at
cbs.dk/graduateadmission
are the application and admission procedures, including deadlines, as well as information about the date when the offer or the rejection of a place of study is made and about the requirement to accept a place of study.
Purpose
2.
The MSc Programme in Business Administration and Philosophy (cand.merc.(fil.)) is a graduate-level, theoretical programme that serves as a continuation of the BSc Programme in Business Administration and Philosophy (HA(fil.)).
(2) The objective of the programme is to impart to the students business economic and business philosophy competencies at an advanced academic level in order to be able to:
From a practical perspective identify, analyse and develop solutions to specific as well as complex business issues within private and public enterprises and organisations.
Develop their competencies within scientific research to enable and qualify them for a continued academic career at a Ph.D.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 16)
text_chunk:
level.
(3) The purpose of the programme is achieved by combining and integrating business and philosophy, using a problem and project-oriented way of working.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 17)
text_chunk:
This will produce and develop the business philosophical competencies of the students by integrating the business economical insight and analysis with the philosophical contemplation and conceptual reflection.
Competency profile
3.
The Study Board has developed a competency profile, which describes the expected learning outcomes of this degree programme. Please see appendix below.
Competency profile for CM(phil)
Purpose and academic profile
At CM(phil) you are taught to leverage philosophical reflection and argumentation as well as in-depth business knowledge in efforts to identify, analyze, and find solutions to pressing issues in business and society.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 18)
text_chunk: Practically, you learn how to use philosophy to identify problems in businesses and practice solving them. Theoretically, the program concentrates on applying philosophical thinking to business studies, in economic theory as well as organization and management studies.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 19)
text_chunk: The program uses philosophy to engage with businesses at three levels. On an individual level, the program teaches you how to think philosophically about theoretical assumptions central for understanding the way people act and make decisions in business settings.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 20)
text_chunk: On an organizational level, the program teaches you how to use philosophy to rethink the way that businesses are managed and organized. On a societal level, the program teaches you how to reflect on the social contexts, natural environments, and markets in which businesses operate.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 21)
text_chunk:
The program also teaches you how the above three levels are interconnected.
As its core, the program integrates business administration and philosophy.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 22)
text_chunk: By activating philosophy within the context of business administration, you learn how to make thinking productive for engaging with complex problems confronting businesses today.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 23)
text_chunk: In particular, you cultivate the ability to ask fundamental questions within a business setting that opens up for new ways of thinking about, for example, competing sets of values and ethical dilemmas relating to the economic, social and environmental performance of firms.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 24)
text_chunk: By doing so, you are able to work with problems relating to the habits of human behavior in firms, how firms are organized and the environment in which firms operate.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 25)
text_chunk:
On this basis, you learn to navigate and work agile in a world that is not one-dimensional, but rather complex, uncertain and ambiguous.
Learning outcomes
Upon completion of the programme, the student is expected to know/be able to:
Place business in a wider societal and environmental context.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 26)
text_chunk: By combining business administration and philosophy, you gain knowledge about the broader societal and environmental context in which organizations operate.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 27)
text_chunk:
Such contexts are comprised of financial institutions, government agencies and other significant stakeholders on both a global and local level as well as the natural surroundings.
Identify actual problems in business settings.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 28)
text_chunk: With the use of philosophical thinking, the program teaches you how to identify problems in business settings. What at first glance appears as a problem might only be the symptom that indicate an underlying cause.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 29)
text_chunk:
To find the real source of a problem demands that you can look beyond surface effects and explore underlying cause. To do so, you learn how work analytically with different forms of data and reflect on the underlying assumptions of given knowledge.
Use thinking to find creative business solutions.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 30)
text_chunk: Finding the problem is the first step towards proposing a solution. Therefore, finding creative solutions is a natural consequence of engaging in philosophical thinking.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 31)
text_chunk:
Philosophy has already been a reflection on basic questions, such as “What should I do?” or “How should we organize society?” The programme brings this reflection into the world of business by activating the ability to reflect on different courses of actions, modes of organization, and responses to problems.
Use rigid thinking to make responsible decisions in business.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 32)
text_chunk: Having the capacity to make responsible decisions therefore require the ability to consider multiple perspectives and considerations. Towards this end, the program teach you how to consider the wider implications that decisions have for the environment, society and the social surroundings.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 33)
text_chunk:
For example, you learn how to apply conceptual tools to empirical cases from business and society (e.g., diversity, sustainability, and labour market concerns) in order to propose responsible decisions.
Navigate competing demands in an increasingly complex world.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 34)
text_chunk: Making responsible decisions presuppose the ability to consider multiple points of view as well as a short term and long term perspective.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 35)
text_chunk: By combining business administration and philosophy, you cultivate the ability to consider multiple interests and take into consideration conflicting perspective when making decisions.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 36)
text_chunk: You learn how to make decisions under uncertainty in a world that is increasingly complex and deal with ambiguous situations.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 37)
text_chunk:
For example, you learn how decision-making in business and in financial markets are not necessarily driven solely by rational considerations but also by habits, norms, and emotions.
Make complex knowledge comprehensible without simplifying it.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 38)
text_chunk: In this program, you acquire an analytic competency to deal with ambiguity and being critical towards the underlying assumptions of knowledge production. You also learn to translate knowledge between different fields of expertise.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 39)
text_chunk: To do so, you learn to learn to independently discuss and apply complex theoretical knowledge by engaging in projects with others.

page_name: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy
section_title: FIL - Master of Science (MSc) in Business Administration and Philosophy (Part 40)
text_chunk:
In doing so, you learn to communicate and make advanced knowledge understandable for a wide audience.
Content and structure
4.
The program consists of seven mandatory courses, four electives and the Master’s Thesis.
The seven mandatory courses are:
1) Organizational Philosophy
2) Philosophical Analysis in Business Studies
3) Finance and Society
4) Philosophical Investigations in Contemporary Worklife
5) Sustainable Business: Critical and Constructive Approaches
6) Behavioral Economics and
7) Economic Sociology of Markets and Innovation
(2) The course “Organizational Philosophy” combines philosophy with organizational practice and strengthens the students’ abilities to identify, analyze and conquer business economic issues within the perspective and framework of professional practice in contemporary organizations.
(3) The course ”Philosophical Analysis in Business Studies” qualifies and strengthens the methodological competencies of the students and enable them to handle both the practical as well as the fundamental  challenges which lies inherent in the business philosophical analysis of tangible business economic issues.
(4) The five courses ”Finance and Society”, ”Philosophical Investigations in Contemporary Worklife”, "Sustainable Business: Critical and Constructive Approaches", “Behavioral Economics” and “Economic Sociology of Markets and Innovation” each integrates philosophical analysis of key issues within business economic theory and practice with a case based and decision oriented approach.
(5) The table below lists the structure of the programme and the ECTS credits of the individual courses.

Assessment
24.
Examinations are either internal or external:
Internal examinations are assessed by one or more teachers (internal examiners) appointed by CBS from among the teachers at the university or from other universities that offer the same or similar study programmes.
External examinations are assessed by one or more internal examiners and one external examiner (in Danish: censor) appointed by the Danish Agency for Higher Education and Science.
(2) It is stipulated in the exam regulations of the individual examination whether it is an internal or an external examination, see link in section 5.
(3) Assessment of the examinations is carried out in accordance with the Grading Scale Order.
(4) Compulsory assignments and class participation, see section 13, are assessed by the teacher(s) of the specific course.

Credit transfer
32.
Programme elements passed at another university are regarded as equivalent to corresponding programme elements covered by these programme regulations.

(2) Approval of pre-approved credit transfer pursuant to subsection (1) may only be granted if, in connection with the application for preapproved credit transfer, the student undertakes to submit to the home university the necessary documentation to show whether the programme elements have been passed or failed upon completion of the programme elements for which pre-approved credit transfer has been granted.

(4) In cases where the programme elements for which pre-approved credit transfer has been granted are, for example, not offered by the host institution, the university may, upon the student's request, change the approval of pre-approved credit transfer pursuant to subsection (1).

Commencement and transition regulations
41.
These Programme Regulations are effective for students enrolled on the programme in September 2024 or later, and for students who are transferred to these Programme Regulations, see section 42.
(2) The 2023 Programme Regulations are repealed as of 1 September 2024, however please see section 42 (2).
42.

2) Students, covered by section 42,  who did not pass the course “Finance and Society” should instead pass the course “The Corporation and Society”.
